instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00928: What is 820-00928? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.820-00840: What is 820-00840? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.3V3_S0: What is 3V3_S0? Abbreviation for PP3V3_S0, a 3.3v power rail present when the machine is in an S0 working state.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> shorted UB000
threads.message:
Hello, I've got an issue with <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> (15" 2017), it came to me dead. Board has no corrosion, but someone obviously reflowed or maybe replaced <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> and CB704 - I guess that's because Louis did this in one of his videos (it's funny how often I'm getting boards from other repair shops where they did exactly the same thing that Louis did with the same board... even if it's a completely different issue, only with similar symptoms). However there is no problem with <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>, so I guess this part is fine.

I measured and found a short on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_TBT_T_S0</SIGNAL> through UB000. After removing UB000, the short is gone, the board boots and partially works. However when I soldered "new" UB000 (from <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> as I don't know where to buy a whole <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with this chip, or the chip itself), it shorted again after connecting the power supply. So I removed UB000 again and measured every pin of UB000 - nothing is shorted in there. Area around <CHIP>U5670</CHIP> looks untouched. <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> works flawlessly with UB000 removed (and with bad UB000 it's partially shorted, that's why the machine cannot turn on I guess).

I've got one last UB000 from <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> and I don't want to waste it the same way as the first one, what else should I check?
Thank you

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> shorted UB000
threads.message:
If you get short on a power rail (or low value to ground), ALWAYS check in diode mode BEFORE power up the board again.
You cannot be sure now if chip has been burnt again, or you had bad solders.
You can compare readings between UB000 and <CHIP>U2800</CHIP>...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> shorted UB000
threads.message: Of course, I measured <SIGNAL>PP3V3_TBT_T_S0</SIGNAL> in diode mode before I connected PS and it was OK. It's burned exactly the same way as the original one - only <SIGNAL>PP3V3_TBT_T_S0</SIGNAL> pads are shorted to GND pads.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> shorted UB000
threads.message:
Really strange, because both chip receive <SIGNAL>3V3_S0</SIGNAL>.
<CHIP>U2800</CHIP> has <CHIP>U8295</CHIP> in the middle and UB000 receives <SIGNAL>3V3_S0</SIGNAL> directly.
But I don't suspect an onvervoltage at <SIGNAL>3V3_S0</SIGNAL>, cause it should damage more things.

Probably you've got a bad chip from donor board.
Change it, check all power rails of UB000 and compare with UB2800.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> shorted UB000
threads.message:
OK, so after changing the chip and measuring everything accessible, it looked fine, so I successfully turned it on. So I guess the first chip was really defective. However the board boots, I can install OS, but after that it hangs on "critical update" issue and I don't know why (SSD is fine as I can install OS on it, battery is fine, touchbar looks fine, no luck with PRAM/SMC reset or installing macOS from scratch on formated drive). Shield on <CHIP>U3900</CHIP> looks quite busted, so I will try to take it off and inspect <CHIP>U3900</CHIP>, but I'm quite afraid of it as it's an underfilled chip with some ridiculously small BGA balls (I think it's smaller than 0.2mm?). Also I don't get why, but someone pulled <CAPACITOR>C7900</CAPACITOR>, <CAPACITOR>C7901</CAPACITOR> and F4500 - I replaced those, but that just fixed clicking of touchpad.

I will probably open a new thread later as this is probably different issue. You can mark this one as solved I think, thank you.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> shorted UB000
threads.message:
There are few things to check on critical update issue on touchbar machine.
Do a search on the forum and see if something helps you.
Did you try installing without touchbar connected?
Also try to start in safe mode.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> shorted UB000
threads.message:
I ruined this board by removing <CHIP>U3900</CHIP> - I tried to be extremely careful and I successfully reballed the chip itself, but it was not possible to clean the underfill from board without ripping a few (not unconnected) pins. It still boots, but it will never work properly again. 

I'm unexperienced with touchbar machines - the question is: Can I buy different used <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> motherboard and use it instead of the old one without any problems? I heard that the TouchID button is linked to the motherboard and cannot be changed, so the button will not work? Or the whole laptop will not work properly (like having that critical update issue because of that)?

Thank you
